docs.title: 🫃 Abdomen CT Protocols
docs.text: Comprehensive protocols for abdominal imaging including liver, pancreas, kidneys, and bowel.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Clinical Scenario Key Protocol Features Oral Contrast Acute abdominal pain Portal venous phase, 70s delay Optional Liver lesion Triphasic (arterial + portal + delayed) No Pancreatic mass Pancreatic phase, 40-50s delay Water only Renal stones Non-contrast, thin slices No Bowel obstruction Portal venous phase No

docs.title: Patient Preparation
docs.text:
• NPO: 4 hours for solid food
  • Oral contrast: Timing varies by indication
  • Hydration: Encourage fluids post-contrast

docs.title: Contrast Dosing
docs.text: \( \text{Volume (mL)} = \text{Weight (kg)} \times 1.5 \text{ mL/kg} \) - Maximum: 150 mL - Flow rate: 3-4 mL/s - Portal venous timing: 70 seconds

docs.title: Safety Considerations
docs.text:
Pre-scan Checklist

  • eGFR ≥30 mL/min for contrast
  • Pregnancy test if applicable
  • Metformin hold if eGFR <30
  • Contrast allergy history

docs.title: CT Abdomen Pelvis with Contrast
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2026-01-02 Author:

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Portal Venous Phase Contrast (70 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis
    • Abdominal pain
    • Oncology staging
    • Infection source
    • Post-operative complications

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours for solids
    • Pre-Medication:
      • Oral contrast: 900 mL Readi-Cat 2 over 90 minutes. Last cup 30 min before scan

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 3 mL/s

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. Consider split bolus technique if eGFR 30-45

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Ensure adequate oral contrast opacification. Scan from diaphragm through pubic symphysis. 70 second delay typical
    • 18-20G IV required. Verify patent IV. May give rectal contrast for distal colon/rectal evaluation. Oral contrast 900mL given 2 hrs before

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history. Pre-medicate if prior reaction
    • Systematic review of all solid organs. Check for free fluid/air. Assess bowel enhancement pattern
    • Arms raised completely. Remove all metal objects from scan range

docs.title: CT Adrenal Mass Protocol
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Thompson

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-Contrast Non-contrast Diaphragm to Kidneys Portal Venous Contrast (70 sec delay) Diaphragm to Kidneys 15 Minute Delay Contrast (900 sec delay) Diaphragm to Kidneys
    • Adrenal mass characterization
    • Adenoma vs metastasis
    • Incidentaloma workup

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 1.5 mL/kg Flow Rate 3-4 mL/s

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • THREE phases: 1) Non-contrast for absolute HU 2) Portal venous 70s 3) 15 MINUTE delayed for washout. All phases cover adrenals
    • 18-20G IV. Patient must wait 15 min for delayed phase

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history. Explain 15 min delay
    • NC: lipid-rich adenoma < 10 HU. Portal venous: enhancement. 15 min delay: calculate washout (adenoma shows washout)
    • Patient wait time 15 min. Measure HU carefully with ROI in same location

docs.title: Additional Reconstructions
docs.text:
Calculate absolute washout: (Enhanced HU - Delayed HU)/(Enhanced HU - NC HU) x 100. >60% suggests adenoma. Measure HU in all phases

docs.title: CT Biphasic Pancreas
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Williams

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Pancreatic Phase Arterial (bolus tracked) Diaphragm to Iliac crests Portal Venous Contrast (70 sec delay) Diaphragm to Iliac crests
    • Pancreatic mass
    • Pancreatitis
    • Pancreatic cyst characterization

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • Water PO: 900 mL water orally 15-30 min before scan for gastric/duodenal distension

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 1.5 mL/kg Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Dual phase: Pancreatic arterial + Portal venous ROI Placement Abdominal aorta Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • TWO phases: Pancreatic phase (40-45s or bolus track) + Portal venous (70s). Water for negative contrast
    • 18-20G IV. Ensure water intake for duodenal distension

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history. Coordinate water intake
    • Pancreatic phase: optimal pancreatic enhancement and small lesions. Portal venous: liver and venous structures
    • Water distension of duodenum helpful. Thin slices for pancreas

docs.title: CT Chest Abdomen Pelvis with Contrast
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Smith

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Portal Venous Phase Contrast (70 sec delay) Lung bases or diaphragm to Pubic symphysis
    • Oncology staging
    • Infection source
    • Abdominal pain
    • Trauma

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours solids. Clear liquids OK up to 2 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • Oral contrast: 250-500 mL neutral (Volumen or water). Give 60-90 min before scan

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 1.5 mL/kg Flow Rate 3-4 mL/s

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. High volume protocol

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Single phase portal venous. Oral contrast for bowel opacification. 40 second injection. 70 second scan delay from start of injection
    • 18-20G IV. Adequate oral contrast intake. Verify renal function

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Portal venous phase optimal for solid organ and bowel assessment. Systematic review all organs
    • Arms fully raised. Neutral oral contrast preferred over positive

docs.title: CT Cystogram
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Kim

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Portal Venous Contrast (70 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis Bladder Filling Contrast (90 sec delay) Standard coverage Cystogram Contrast (100 sec delay) Iliac crests to Below bladder Post-Void Contrast (Immediate delay) Iliac crests to Below bladder
    • Bladder rupture
    • Bladder injury
    • Post-operative bladder assessment
    • Hematuria with bladder concern

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • Bladder contrast: 350-400 mL dilute contrast (30 mL contrast in 350 mL saline)

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 100 mL Flow Rate 3-4 mL/s

    eGFR > 30 for IV. Bladder instillation via Foley

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • TWO components: 1) CT with IV contrast portal venous 2) Bladder filling via Foley with dilute contrast 3) Scan distended bladder 4) Post-void scan. Coordinate with nursing
    • Foley catheter required. Dilute contrast preparation (30mL in 350mL saline). Gravity fill bladder. Patient signals fullness

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Foley placement. Prepare dilute contrast
    • Portal venous: solid organs. Cystogram: bladder integrity extravasation. Post-void: small leaks
    • Adequate bladder distension critical. Gravity fill slowly. Clamp Foley during scan

docs.title: CT Enterography
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Martinez

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Enteric Phase Contrast (45 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis
    • Crohn disease
    • Small bowel obstruction
    • Obscure GI bleeding
    • Small bowel mass

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours solids
    • Pre-Medication:
      • Neutral oral contrast (VoLumen): 1st bottle (450mL) at 90 min. 2nd bottle (450mL) at 60 min. Half bottle (225mL) at 30 min. Other half (225mL) at 5 min before scan

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 1.5 mL/kg Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. High flow rate

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Enterographic phase (45 sec). High volume neutral oral for bowel distension. 25 second injection. Scan 45 sec from start
    • 18-20G IV. Ensure adequate oral contrast intake (total ~1350mL). May need anti-peristaltic agent

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history. Coordinate oral contrast timing
    • Assess bowel wall enhancement and thickness. Look for strictures fistulas abscesses. Mesenteric vascularity
    • Adequate oral contrast distension critical. High injection rate

docs.title: CT IVP (Intravenous Pyelogram)
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Anderson

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-Contrast (optional) Non-contrast Top kidneys to Pubic symphysis Early Portal Venous Contrast (60 sec from 1st delay) Top kidneys to Iliac crests Excretory Phase Contrast (90-120 sec from 2nd delay) Top kidneys to Pubic symphysis
    • Hematuria
    • Urothelial carcinoma
    • Collecting system evaluation
    • Hydronephrosis

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume Split bolus: 1st injection 1.1 mL/kg + 2nd injection 0.4 mL/kg Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Split bolus technique

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. Split bolus for combined nephrographic and excretory phases

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • COMPLEX protocol: 1) NC (optional stone protocol) 2) 1st contrast injection 3) Early PV 60s after 1st 4) WAIT 5-7 min 5) 2nd injection + saline 6) Excretory/IVP 90-120s after 2nd
    • 18-20G IV. Split bolus technique. May give Lasix 10-20mg IV for better opacification

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • NC optional: detect stones. Early PV: renal parenchyma. Excretory: collecting system ureters bladder for urothelial lesions
    • Split bolus critical for opacification. Lasix may help. Prone imaging optional for ureters

docs.title: CT KUB Non-Contrast
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Johnson

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-Contrast KUB Non-contrast Top of kidneys to Pubic symphysis
    • Nephrolithiasis
    • Renal colic
    • Flank pain
    • Hematuria

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: None required

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    No Intravenous Contrast

    This protocol does not require IV contrast administration.

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • LOW DOSE protocol. Reduced mAs. Cover kidneys to pubic symphysis. Stone protocol settings
    • No IV needed. No oral contrast. Explain low radiation technique

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: N/A
    • Allergy: N/A
    • Look for stones - measure size and location. Check for hydronephrosis. Assess for alternative diagnoses
    • Low dose protocol. Reduced mAs. Image quality adequate for stones

docs.title: CT Renal Mass Protocol
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Davis

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-Contrast Non-contrast Top kidneys to Iliac crests Corticomedullary Contrast (20 sec delay) Top kidneys to Iliac crests Nephrographic/IVP Contrast (90-120 sec from 2nd injection delay) Top kidneys to Pubic symphysis
    • Renal mass characterization
    • Renal cell carcinoma staging
    • Complex cyst evaluation

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume Split bolus: 1st injection 1.1 mL/kg + 2nd injection 0.4 mL/kg Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Split bolus technique

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. Split bolus technique

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • COMPLEX protocol: 1) NC 2) 1st contrast injection 3) Arterial 20s after 1st 4) WAIT 5-7 min 5) 2nd injection + saline 6) IVP/nephrographic 90-120s after 2nd
    • 18-20G IV. Explain split bolus technique and delay

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • NC: fat/calcification. Arterial: vascular anatomy and hypervascular masses. Nephrographic/IVP: delayed enhancement and collecting system
    • Split bolus timing critical. 5-7 min wait between injections

docs.title: CT Triple Phase Liver
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Lee

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-Contrast Non-contrast Diaphragm to Iliac crests Late Arterial Arterial (bolus tracked) Diaphragm to Iliac crests Portal Venous Contrast (70 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis Delayed Phase Contrast (300 sec delay) Diaphragm to Iliac crests
    • Liver lesion characterization
    • HCC surveillance
    • Liver mass protocol

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • None typically. Oral contrast optional

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 1.5 mL/kg Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Triple phase: NC + Arterial + Portal Venous + Delayed ROI Placement Abdominal aorta Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • FOUR acquisitions: 1) NC abdomen 2) Late arterial (bolus track or 30-35s) 3) Portal venous 70s 4) Delayed 5 min. FOV: Abdomen for NC/Art/Delay. Full AP for PV
    • 18-20G IV. High flow rate critical

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • NC: characterize lesion. Arterial: hypervascular lesions HCC. Portal: most liver lesions. Delayed: washout pattern
    • High flow rate. Extended 5 min delay. Breath hold coaching

docs.title: Heart Rate Management
docs.text:
Critical for Image Quality

Target HR: <60 bpm for coronary CTA

Beta Blocker Protocol: - Metoprolol 25-100 mg PO (1 hour before) - IV Metoprolol 5 mg increments (max 15 mg)

Contraindications: - Severe asthma/COPD - Heart block (2nd/3rd degree) - SBP <100 mmHg

docs.title: Nitroglycerin
docs.text:
• Dose: 0.4-0.8 mg SL
  • Timing: 3-5 min before scan
  • Contraindications: Recent PDE5 inhibitor, SBP <90

docs.title: Calcium Score
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2026-02-02 Author:

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Calcium Score Non-contrast Carina to Below heart
    • Cardiovascular risk assessment
    • Chest pain low-intermediate risk
    • Asymptomatic screening
    • Elevated HLD
    • Significant cardiovascular risk factors

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine feet-first
    • NPO Status: No caffeine day of exam
    • Pre-Medication:
      • HR control not needed for calcium score

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    No Intravenous Contrast

    This protocol does not require IV contrast administration.

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Prospective ECG gating.
    • Suspended Respiration breathing instructions.
    • For single source CT: Target End Diastole if HR < 63BPM, else target End diastole and end systole. For dual source CT: Target End diastole if HR <79, else target end systole. Ensure ECG leads well connected, Goal: <= 60 BPM, regular (+/- 5).
    • No IV needed.

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: N/A
    • Allergy: N/A
    • Check breathing motion on lung FOV. Calculate Agatston score. Report percentile for age/sex. Document coronary calcification distribution
    • Good ECG tracing essential. Patient breath hold coaching

docs.title: Coronary CTA Post-CABG
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2026-02-02 Author:

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Calcium Score Non-contrast Lung apices to Diaphragm Gated CTA Arterial (bolus tracked) Lung apices to 2cm below heart apex
    • Post-CABG graft patency assessment
    • Recurrent chest pain post-bypass

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine feet-first
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • HR < 60 target.
      • Metoprolol 5mg IV increments up to 15mg. Metoprolol contraindications include sBP < 100, 2nd/3rd degree heart block, and inhaler dependent asthma.
      • Nitroglycerin 0.4mg SL 5 minutes before scan. Nitroglycerin contraindications include sBP < 100, PDE5 inhibitors within 48 hrs, severe aortic stenosis.

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 1.1 mL/kg Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Ascending aorta Trigger (HU) 200 HU

    Use full dose if GFR > 30

    If GFR < 30

    Max Contrast = \(2*\left[\frac{\text{Patient Weight}}{75 \text{ kg}} * \text{eGFR}\right]\)

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Non-valsalva breathing technique, cardiac breathing instruction. Put in study notes if patient unable to follow breathing instructions.
    • If high HR variability, can trigger by millisecond (200ms - 450 ms pulse range). Revolution CT is better for Afib.
    • Target End diastole if HR < 65bpm. Target End systole if HR > 86bpm. Target End diastole to End systole if HR 66 - 75 bpm
    • 20G IV minimum. Check for metoprolol or nitroglycerin contraindications. Nitro is priority over metoprolol if BP is borderline.

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Assess all grafts: LIMA RIMA SVG. Check anastomoses. Native vessel disease. Graft patency vs occlusion. Check functional series for WMA.
    • Full chest coverage essential. Extended FOV. Low pitch for retrospective gating

docs.title: Coronary CTA
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2026-02-02 Author:

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Calcium Score Non-contrast Carina to Below heart Gated CTA Arterial (bolus tracked) 2cm above LAD to 2cm below heart apex
    • Intermediate chest pain
    • Suspected infarct
    • Coronary artery dissection or aneurysm
    • Anomalous coronary artery
    • Stent patency

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine feet-first
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • HR < 60 target.
      • Metoprolol 5mg IV increments up to 15mg. Metoprolol contraindications include sBP < 100, 2nd/3rd degree heart block, and inhaler dependent asthma.
      • Nitroglycerin 0.4mg SL 5 minutes before scan. Nitroglycerin contraindications include sBP < 100, PDE5 inhibitors within 48 hrs, severe aortic stenosis.

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 1.1 mL/kg Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Ascending aorta Trigger (HU) 200 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30, If low eGFR can use low dose calculation Maximum Contrast Dose = [(Patient Weight in kg/75 kg) * eGFR] *2

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Non-valsalva breathing technique, cardiac breathing instruction. Put in study notes if patient unable to follow breathing instructions.
    • If high HR variability, can trigger by millisecond (200ms - 450 ms pulse range). Revolution CT is better for Afib.
    • Target End diastole if HR < 65bpm. Target End systole if HR > 86bpm. Target End diastole to End systole if HR 66 - 75 bpm
    • 20G IV minimum. Check for metoprolol or nitroglycerin contraindications. Nitro is priority over metoprolol if BP is borderline.

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Calculate Agatston score. Give CAD-RADS score. Check function look for potential focal wall motion abnormalities
    • Full chest coverage essential. Extended FOV. Low pitch for retrospective gating

docs.title: Endocarditis/Cardiac Mass
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2026-02-02 Author:

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-contrast Non-contrast Top of heart to Below heart Gated CTA Contrast (30 sec delay) Top of heart to Below heart Delayed phase Contrast (70 sec delay) Top of heart to Below heart
    • Endocarditis
    • Cardiac mass
    • Valve vegetation
    • Intracardiac thrombus

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine feet-first
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • HR < 65 preferred. No premedication typically given.

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 1.6 mL/kg Flow Rate 3-4 mL/s

    Full dose if eGFR > 30, If low eGFR can use low dose calculation Maximum Contrast Dose = [(Patient Weight in kg/75 kg) * eGFR] *2

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Non-valsalva breathing technique, cardiac breathing instruction.
    • Injection duration is fixed 35 sec fixed 30 sec scan delay. Retrospective gating trigger at 30-70% (End sys - end dia). Reconstruct at 5% intervals.
    • 18-20G IV. HR control helpful but not critical

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Assess all valves for vegetations. Evaluate myocardium for abscess. Look for intracardiac masses. Check for complications
    • Multiple cardiac phases helpful for valve motion. Thin slices for vegetations

docs.title: Gated CTA CAP Sternotomy Revision
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Williams

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Gated CTA Chest Arterial (bolus tracked) Thoracic inlet to Diaphragm Flash AP Contrast (Immediate delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis Venogram Chest Contrast (60 sec delay) Thoracic inlet to Diaphragm
    • Pre-operative planning for redo sternotomy
    • Retrosternal structures assessment

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • HR < 65. Metoprolol IV prn. Nitro 0.4mg SL

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 150 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Triple phase: Gated chest + AP arterial + Chest venous ROI Placement Ascending aorta Trigger (HU) 180 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. Large volume protocol

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • THREE acquisitions: 1) Gated CHEST 2) Flash AP arterial 3) CHEST venogram 60 sec delay. Venous for retrosternal structures
    • 20G IV

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Large contrast load - verify renal function
    • Gated: cardiac anatomy. Arterial: systemic vessels. VENOUS: retrosternal veins and adherent structures critical for surgical planning
    • Venous phase critical for surgical planning. Map all retrosternal structures

docs.title: Gated CTA CAP
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Lee

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Gated CTA Chest Arterial (bolus tracked) Thoracic inlet to Diaphragm Flash CTA AP Contrast (Immediate after chest delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis
    • Aortic dissection
    • Aortic aneurysm with cardiac involvement
    • Combined cardiac and aortic pathology

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • HR < 65 target. Metoprolol 5mg IV prn. Nitro 0.4mg SL

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 140 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Dual phase: Gated chest + Flash AP ROI Placement Ascending aorta Trigger (HU) 180 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. Large volume needed

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • TWO acquisitions: 1) Gated retrospective CHEST 2) Flash helical ABDOMEN/PELVIS. Chest gated for aortic root. AP flash arterial
    • 20G IV minimum

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Gated chest: assess aortic root valve coronaries. Flash AP: assess aorta and branches. Combined cardiac and vascular
    • Arms up. Careful timing between gated and flash acquisitions

docs.title: Gated CTA Chest Post-op Cardiac Valve
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Thompson

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Gated CTA Arterial (bolus tracked) Top of heart to Below heart
    • Post-operative valve assessment
    • Prosthetic valve evaluation
    • Post-surgical complications

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine feet-first
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • HR < 65 preferred. Metoprolol if needed

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 1.3 mL/kg Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Ascending aorta Trigger (HU) 200 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. Increased volume for metal artifact

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Retrospective gating. INCREASED kV to 130-140 for metal artifact reduction. Increased contrast 1.3 mL/kg. Extended reconstruction phases
    • 20G IV minimum

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Assess prosthetic valve function. Look for paravalvular leak. Evaluate perivalvular complications. Metal artifact reduction critical
    • High kV (130-140) critical for metal artifact. Increased contrast volume

docs.title: Gated CTA Chest
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Anderson

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-contrast Non-contrast Top of heart to Below heart Gated CTA Arterial (bolus tracked) Top of heart to Below heart Stent delay (optional) Contrast (40 sec delay) Top of heart to Below heart
    • Coronary artery disease
    • Chest pain
    • Anomalous coronaries
    • Coronary CTA

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine feet-first
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • HR < 60 target. Metoprolol 5mg IV up to 15mg total. Nitro 0.4mg SL. Check BP > 100

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 1.1 mL/kg Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Ascending aorta Trigger (HU) 200 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Retrospective ECG gating. Cover heart. Bolus tracking in ascending aorta. Optional stent protocol: add 40 sec delayed phase
    • 20G IV minimum. HR control critical. Nitro administration. Monitor BP

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check metoprolol contraindications
    • Assess coronaries for stenosis plaque. Evaluate anomalous anatomy. Stent patency if applicable. Cardiac function from multi-phase
    • HR control essential. Coach breathing. Gating quality check

docs.title: Gated CTA Heart Left Atrial Mapping
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Kim

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Gated CTA Arterial (bolus tracked) Pulmonary veins to Below LA
    • Pre-ablation planning
    • Atrial fibrillation
    • Pulmonary vein anatomy

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine feet-first
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • HR < 65 preferred. Metoprolol if needed. Nitro not typically required

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 1.1 mL/kg Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Ascending aorta Trigger (HU) 200 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Retrospective gating. Focus on left atrium and pulmonary veins. Thin slices critical. Extended coverage for all PV ostia
    • 20G IV

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Map pulmonary vein anatomy (number ostia diameters). Left atrial appendage morphology. Esophageal position. LA size
    • Thin slices essential. Complete PV coverage. Document variants

docs.title: 🫁 Chest CT Protocols
docs.text: Protocols for thoracic imaging including lung parenchyma, mediastinum, and pulmonary vasculature.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Clinical Scenario Key Protocol Features Contrast Pulmonary embolism Bolus tracking, PA trigger Yes ILD/fibrosis HRCT, 1mm slices No Lung nodule Thin slices, no contrast No Oncology staging Portal venous phase Yes

docs.title: Optimal Timing
docs.text:
• ROI: Main pulmonary artery
  • Trigger: 100-150 HU
  • Delay: 4-5 seconds
  • Direction: Craniocaudal

High-Risk PE Signs

  • RV/LV ratio >1.0
  • Septal bowing
  • IVC reflux
  • Bilateral central PE

docs.title: HRCT Technique
docs.text:
• Slice thickness: 1-1.25 mm
  • High-resolution kernel
  • Expiratory views for air trapping
  • Prone imaging if needed

docs.title: Dose Optimization
docs.text:
• Use iterative reconstruction
  • Low-dose for nodule follow-up (<1 mSv)
  • Bismuth shielding when appropriate

docs.title: CT Pulmonary Embolism
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2026-01-01 Author:

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Pulmonary Angiogram Arterial (bolus tracked) Lung apices to Adrenal glands
    • Suspected pulmonary embolism
    • Acute dyspnea
    • Chest pain with elevated D-dimer

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine feet-first with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 2 hours recommended
    • Pre-Medication:
      • None required

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 100 mL Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Main Pulmonary Artery Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. Reduce if eGFR 30-60

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Caudocranial scan direction. Coach breath hold. ROI in main PA at level of bifurcation
    • 20G or larger IV in antecubital preferred. Verify good flow before injection

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check iodine allergy history and prior reactions
    • Assess RV/LV ratio. Look for signs of right heart strain. Check for DVT in leg veins if imaged
    • Arms fully raised to reduce beam hardening

docs.title: Dynamic Airway CT
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Lee

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Inspiration Contrast (Full inspiration delay) Thoracic inlet to Carina+10cm Mid-Expiration Contrast (Forced mid-expiration delay) Thoracic inlet to Carina+10cm Cine (optional) Contrast (Continuous breathing delay) Carina level to Single slice
    • Tracheomalacia
    • Bronchomalacia
    • Expiratory central airway collapse
    • EDAC

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: N/A

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    No Intravenous Contrast

    This protocol does not require IV contrast administration.

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • TWO acquisitions: 1) INSPIRATION carina to carina+10cm 2) MID-EXPIRATION same level. Cine if available. Airway reconstructions required
    • No IV. Coach dynamic breathing. May need forced expiration

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: N/A
    • Allergy: N/A
    • Measure tracheal collapse percentage. >50% collapse suggests tracheomalacia. Assess bronchi
    • Coach forced expiration. Exact same level both phases

    • NPO Status: N/A

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks

    • Position patient prone safely. Cushion support. Breath hold coaching

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: N/A
    • Allergy: N/A
    • Differentiate dependent atelectasis from true fibrosis. Posterior lung better aerated prone
    • Safe prone positioning. Compare to supine if available

    • No IV. Coach complete inspiration and complete expiration

    Safety First

    • Allergy: N/A

    • Complete exhalation critical for RV. Volumetric contiguous

Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Patel

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CT Ankle Contrast (N/A or 60s if contrast delay) Distal tib/fib to Hindfoot

    • Allergy: N/A or check allergy
    • Malleolar fractures. Tibial plafond. Talus. Calcaneus. Syndesmosis. Ligaments on contrast
    • Bilateral scout for symmetry. Submillimeter for 3D

docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Johnson

    • Renal Function: N/A
    • Allergy: N/A
    • Urate crystals color-coded on DECT. Tophi. Joint erosions. Soft tissue deposits. Quantify urate burden
    • Dual energy preferred for urate detection

docs.title: MSK Protocol General
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Lee

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-contrast Non-contrast Region to Region Contrast phase Contrast (60-90 sec if done delay) Region to Region Delayed phase Contrast (5-10 min if done delay) Region to Region
    • Pre-operative planning
    • Post-operative assessment
    • Infection
    • Mass
    • Soft tissue tumor
    • Abscess

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Depends on body part
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours if contrast

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 if contrast Volume 100 mL if contrast Flow Rate 2-3 mL/s

    Contrast for infection mass post-op. NC for trauma hardware

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Field of view specific to region. Submillimeter if 3D needed. NC and/or contrast based on indication. Delayed phase (5-10 min) for infection/tumor
    • IV for contrast studies. Document indication

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: N/A or eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: N/A or check allergy
    • NC: baseline bone soft tissue. Contrast: enhancement pattern. Delayed: washout or persistent enhancement. 3D for surgical planning
    • Tailor protocol to clinical question. Bilateral for comparison

docs.title: Brain Stroke Protocol
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Williams

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage NC Head Non-contrast Vertex to Foramen magnum CTA Head Arterial (bolus tracked) Skull base to Vertex CTA Neck Contrast (Continues from head delay) Aortic arch to Skull base CTP (optional) Contrast (Auto-triggered delay) Basal ganglia level to 8cm slab
    • Acute stroke
    • CVA
    • Neurological deficit < 24 hours
    • Stroke code

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine head-first
    • NPO Status: None - emergency

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 for CTA/CTP Volume 100 mL Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Multi-phase stroke protocol ROI Placement Multiple ROIs Trigger (HU) Varies

    Proceed emergently. Time is brain

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • STAT protocol: 1) NC Head 2) CTA Head/Neck (aortic arch to vertex) 3) CTP (optional). Minimize door-to-scan time
    • No IV for NC. Large bore for CTA/CTP. STAT coordination

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Emergency proceed
    • Allergy: STAT protocol
    • NC: hemorrhage early ischemia hyperdense vessel. CTA: LVO large vessel occlusion. CTP: penumbra core mismatch
    • STAT protocol. Minimize delays. LVO detection critical

docs.title: CT Parathyroid 4D
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Kim

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-Contrast Non-contrast Skull base to Carina Arterial Phase Contrast (25 sec delay) Skull base to Carina Venous Phase Contrast (55 sec delay) Skull base to Carina Delayed Phase Contrast (90 sec delay) Skull base to Carina
    • Hyperparathyroidism
    • Parathyroid adenoma localization
    • Pre-operative parathyroid planning

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine head-first with arms down
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 75-100 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method 4D multi-phase ROI Placement Carotid artery Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • FOUR phases: 1) NC 2) Arterial 25s 3) Venous 55s 4) Delayed/washout 90s. Skull base to mediastinum. Parathyroid enhances early washes out
    • 18-20G IV. High flow rate for arterial

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • NC: baseline. Arterial: parathyroid lights up. Venous: thyroid enhances. Delayed: parathyroid washes out faster than thyroid
    • Four phase critical. Look for early enhancement and washout

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    No Intravenous Contrast

    This protocol does not require IV contrast administration.

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Minimize patient motion. Gantry angle parallel to skull base to reduce orbital dose. Ensure head straight
    • No IV required. Explain importance of staying still

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: N/A
    • Allergy: N/A
    • Look for hyperdense MCA sign. Assess grey-white differentiation. Check for hemorrhage and mass effect
    • Remove dentures and hearing aids. Secure head in holder

docs.title: Pregnant Trauma CT AP
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Anderson

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Portal Venous AP Contrast (70 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis
    • Pregnant trauma patient
    • Multi-trauma pregnancy
    • Maternal injury assessment

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with left lateral tilt if possible
    • NPO Status: None - trauma

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 3 mL/s

    Proceed with trauma indication. Document medical necessity and gestational age

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Portal venous phase 70s. SINGLE PHASE to minimize fetal radiation. Shield uterus if injury distant. Document weeks gestation
    • Pregnancy documented. Fetal heart tones if equipment available. Shield if possible

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Check if known
    • Allergy: Trauma indication documented
    • Assess maternal injuries. Minimize fetal radiation exposure. Document placental injury if visible
    • Document gestational age. Shield fetus if possible. Minimize radiation

docs.title: Trauma Code AAA
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Davis

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-Contrast CAP Non-contrast Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis Arterial CAP Contrast (25-30 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis Portal Venous CAP Contrast (70 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis
    • Ruptured AAA
    • Aortic emergency
    • Hemodynamic instability with abdominal pain

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: None - emergency

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Triple phase: NC + Arterial + Portal venous ROI Placement Abdominal aorta Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Proceed emergently. Life-saving indication

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • RAPID triple phase: 1) NC CAP (hematoma) 2) Arterial CAP (active bleed bolus track 25-30s) 3) Portal venous CAP (70s). STAT protocol
    • Large bore IV 18G minimum. Blood products ready

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Emergent - proceed
    • Allergy: Document emergency
    • NC: retroperitoneal hematoma. Arterial: active extravasation aneurysm morphology. Portal: solid organs
    • STAT protocol. Minimize delays. Notify vascular surgery

Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Lee

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Chest Arterial (bolus tracked) Lung apices to Diaphragm Portal Venous AP Contrast (70 sec from start delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis
    • Blunt thoracic trauma
    • Aortic injury
    • Great vessel injury
    • Multi-trauma

  • 2. Patient Prep

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Dual phase: CTA Chest arterial + Portal venous AP ROI Placement Descending aorta Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Proceed if possible. Document medical necessity

  • 4. Special Notes

    • Large bore IV 18-20G. Verify flow

    • Renal Function: eGFR > 30 if known
    • Allergy: Trauma indication
    • Chest arterial: aortic injury (intimal flap pseudoaneurysm). AP portal venous: solid organ injury
    • Trauma indication. Fast scan. Good IV essential

docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Williams

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Arterial Arterial (bolus tracked) Coverage as needed to Distal to injury
    • Extremity vascular injury
    • Penetrating trauma
    • Fracture with vascular concern
    • Pulseless extremity

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine legs extended
    • NPO Status: None - trauma

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Omnipaque 350 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Abdominal aorta or proximal to injury Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Proceed with trauma indication

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Extend coverage based on injury. Aorta to ankles if bilateral. May do unilateral focused study. Arterial phase
    • 18-20G IV. May need proximal IV if arm injury

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Check if available
    • Allergy: Trauma indication
    • Assess arterial injury: transection pseudoaneurysm occlusion extravasation. Evaluate fracture relationship to vessels
    • Tailor coverage to injury. Fast acquisition

docs.title: 🩸 Vascular CT Protocols
docs.text: Vascular imaging protocols including aorta, peripheral vessels, and runoff studies.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Clinical Scenario Key Protocol Features Timing Aortic dissection Arterial phase, non-gated 25-30s AAA evaluation Arterial + delayed 30s + 70s Peripheral runoff Multi-phase, bolus chase Variable Renal arteries Arterial phase only 20-25s

docs.title: Arterial Phase Timing
docs.text: \[ \text{Delay} = \text{Circulation Time} + 5-8 \text{ seconds} \]

docs.title: Multi-Phase Protocols
docs.text:
• Arterial: 25-30 seconds
  • Portal venous: 70 seconds
  • Delayed: 180-300 seconds

docs.title: Bolus Tracking
docs.text:
• Aortic arch: For head/neck CTA
  • Descending aorta: For thoracic/abdominal
  • Trigger: 150-200 HU

Common Pitfalls

  • Early scan → poor arterial opacification
  • Late scan → venous contamination
  • Low flow rate → streak artifacts

docs.title: CTA Abdomen Pelvis
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Martinez

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Arterial Arterial (bolus tracked) Diaphragm to Femoral heads
    • Abdominal aortic aneurysm
    • Mesenteric ischemia
    • Renal artery stenosis
    • Pre-EVAR planning

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • Oral contrast optional - omit for vascular indication

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Abdominal aorta at celiac Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. Critical for renal artery assessment

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Caudocranial scan direction. Include renal arteries to femoral bifurcation minimum
    • 18-20G IV antecubital

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Measure AAA if present. Assess renal and mesenteric arteries. Evaluate iliac vessels
    • Arms raised. No oral contrast for pure vascular study

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Arterial Arterial (bolus tracked) Xiphoid to Pubic symphysis
    • Pre-operative planning for DIEP flap breast reconstruction

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms at sides or on chest
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 100 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Abdominal aorta Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Scan from xiphoid to pubic symphysis. Focus on anterior abdominal wall perforators. Arterial phase critical
    • 18-20G IV

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Map perforator locations. Measure vessel caliber. Identify dominant perforators. Note relationship to rectus
    • Arms positioned to not obscure anterior abdominal wall

docs.title: CTA for GI Bleed
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2026-01-05 Author:

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Arterial Phase Contrast (25 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis Portal Venous Phase Contrast (70 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis Delayed Phase Contrast (90-180 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis
    • Active GI bleeding
    • Hematemesis
    • Melena with hemodynamic instability
    • Hematochezia

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO if possible (emergent study)

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 5 mL/s Timing Method Triple phase: Arterial + Portal Venous + Delayed ROI Placement Abdominal aorta Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Can proceed with eGFR > 30 in emergency. Document medical necessity

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • High flow rate critical for arterial phase. Scan arterial at 25 sec then portal at 70 sec then delayed at 90-180 sec. Look for active extravasation
    • Large bore IV 18-20G essential. Must achieve 5 mL/s flow rate. Verify with saline test

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: eGFR > 30 preferred but can proceed emergently
    • Allergy: Document allergy history. Emergency indication overrides mild allergy
    • Look for arterial extravasation (early) and pooling (delayed). Note location and potential source vessel
    • Arms raised to avoid artifacts. Fast table speed to cover area quickly in arterial phase

docs.title: CTA Head and Neck (Arch to Vertex)
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2026-01-04 Author:

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Neck Arterial (bolus tracked) Aortic arch to Skull base CTA Head Contrast (Immediate delay) Skull base to Vertex
    • Stroke workup
    • Carotid stenosis
    • Vertebral artery dissection
    • Aneurysm screening

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine head-first with arms at sides
    • NPO Status: NPO 2 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • None typically. Consider anxiolytic if severe claustrophobia

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 80-100 mL Flow Rate 4-5 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Aortic arch Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Scan from aortic arch through vertex. Use bolus tracking in arch. Minimize dental artifact with gantry angulation
    • Good antecubital IV access required - 20G minimum. Verify injection site for extravasation risk

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history and renal function
    • Evaluate complete circle of Willis. Assess carotid bifurcations. Look for dissection. Check aneurysms
    • Remove dentures. Minimize swallowing during neck acquisition

docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Kim

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Arterial Arterial (bolus tracked) Iliac crest to Ankle
    • Pre-operative planning for free flap harvest (fibula ALT anterolateral thigh)

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with legs extended
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 120 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Femoral artery Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks

    • 18-20G IV

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Map perforator vessels. Measure vessel caliber and length. Identify dominant pedicle. Note anatomic variants
    • Legs straight and not rotated. Mark skin over region of interest if possible

docs.title: CTA Lower Extremity Runoff for PAD
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Anderson

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Arterial Arterial (bolus tracked) Renal arteries to Ankle
    • Peripheral arterial disease
    • Claudication
    • Critical limb ischemia
    • Pre-operative bypass planning

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised. Legs straight
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 150 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Abdominal aorta Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. May need larger volume for slow flow

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Scan from renal arteries to feet. Use automatic bolus tracking. Extend delay if known severe PAD. Cover tibial vessels to ankle
    • 18-20G IV antecubital

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Assess aortoiliac femoral popliteal and tibial vessels. Grade stenoses. Identify occlusions. Assess runoff vessels
    • Ensure legs are straight and not rotated. Remove shoes and metal

docs.title: CTA Mesenteric Ischemia
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Lee

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Arterial Phase Contrast (25 sec delay) Diaphragm to Iliac crests Portal Venous Contrast (70 sec delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis
    • Acute mesenteric ischemia
    • Chronic mesenteric ischemia
    • Bowel infarction

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO (emergent - as patient presents)
    • Pre-Medication:
      • None - emergent study

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 5 mL/s Timing Method Dual phase: Arterial + Portal Venous ROI Placement Abdominal aorta at celiac Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Proceed if eGFR > 30. Emergency indication in acute setting

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Arterial phase at 25 sec for vessel assessment. Portal venous at 70 sec for bowel perfusion. High flow rate critical
    • 18G IV required for 5 mL/s flow. Must be patent

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: eGFR > 30 preferred
    • Allergy: Emergency study - document indication
    • Arterial: assess celiac SMA IMA origins. Portal: look for bowel wall enhancement. Check for pneumatosis
    • Fast scan. High flow rate essential

docs.title: CTA Pelvis Cyclist Iliac Artery Maneuver
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Rodriguez

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Resting Position Arterial (bolus tracked) L3 to Mid femur CTA Hip Flexion Contrast (Immediately after delay) L3 to Mid femur
    • External iliac artery endofibrosis
    • Cyclist with exercise-induced leg symptoms

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine initially then with hip flexion
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 100 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Dual position: Resting + Hip flexion cycling position ROI Placement External iliac artery Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • TWO acquisitions: 1) Resting supine 2) Hip flexion simulating cycling position. Bilateral imaging for comparison
    • 18-20G IV

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history. Explain hip flexion positioning
    • Compare resting vs flexed position. Look for iliac artery kinking stenosis or occlusion with hip flexion. Common in competitive cyclists
    • Position patient with knees bent and hips flexed to simulate cycling. May need positioning aids

docs.title: CTA Pelvis Prostate Artery Embolization
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Jackson

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Arterial Arterial (bolus tracked) L3 to Proximal femur
    • Pre-procedural planning for prostate artery embolization
    • Benign prostatic hyperplasia

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 100 mL Flow Rate 3-4 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Common iliac artery Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Scan from L3 to proximal femur. Arterial phase essential. Focus on internal iliac branches and prostate supply
    • 18-20G IV

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Identify prostate artery origins (usually anterior division of internal iliac). Map anatomy for IR. Note variants and anastomoses
    • Full bladder helpful for prostate visualization. Coordinate with IR before scan

docs.title: CTA Popliteal Entrapment
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Thompson

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Neutral Position Arterial (bolus tracked) Distal femur to Ankle CTA Plantarflexion Contrast (Immediately after delay) Distal femur to Ankle
    • Popliteal entrapment syndrome
    • Exercise-induced leg pain
    • Young patient with claudication

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with legs extended in neutral position
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 100 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Dual position: Neutral + Plantarflexion ROI Placement Popliteal artery Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • TWO acquisitions required: 1) Neutral position 2) Active plantarflexion. Both legs scanned for comparison. Coach patient on plantarflexion technique
    • 18-20G IV antecubital

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history. Explain plantarflexion maneuver to patient
    • Compare neutral vs plantarflexion images. Look for popliteal artery compression deviation or occlusion with plantarflexion. Assess muscle anatomy
    • Coach patient on maintaining plantarflexion during second acquisition. Use foot straps if needed

docs.title: CTA SCAD/FMD Protocol
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Hayes

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage Non-contrast Head Non-contrast Vertex to Foramen magnum CTA Neck Arterial (bolus tracked) Aortic arch to Vertex CTA CAP Contrast (35 sec after neck delay) Diaphragm to Pubic symphysis Post-contrast Head Contrast (After CAP delay) Vertex to Foramen magnum
    • Spontaneous coronary artery dissection screening
    • Fibromuscular dysplasia screening
    • Multi-vessel arterial assessment

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms initially UP then DOWN
    • NPO Status: NPO 4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 150 mL total Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Multi-phase: NC Head + CTA Neck + CTA CAP arms up + Post-contrast Head arms down ROI Placement Multiple ROIs Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30. Large volume for multiple phases

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • FOUR acquisitions: 1) NC Head arms down 2) CTA Neck bolus track 3) CTA CAP arms up 4) Post Head arms down. Patient repositions arms between scans
    • 20G IV minimum. Verify good flow for multiple phases

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history. Explain arm repositioning
    • Screen all vascular beds for FMD. Look for beading stenosis aneurysm dissection. Assess renal carotid vertebral intracranial arteries
    • Coach patient on arm repositioning. Multiple phases require good IV. Plan scan sequence carefully

docs.title: CTA Upper Extremity
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Davis

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTA Arterial Arterial (bolus tracked) Aortic arch to Fingertips
    • Upper extremity arterial insufficiency
    • Trauma
    • Dialysis access planning
    • Thoracic outlet syndrome

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with affected arm raised above head or at side depending on indication
    • NPO Status: NPO 2 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 100 mL Flow Rate 4 mL/s Timing Method Bolus Tracking ROI Placement Subclavian artery Trigger (HU) 150 HU

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Scan from aortic arch to fingertips. May need bilateral for comparison. Position arm to demonstrate pathology
    • 20G IV in contralateral arm

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history. IV in opposite arm
    • Assess subclavian axillary brachial radial ulnar arteries. Look for stenosis occlusion or injury
    • Position arm to avoid overlap with torso. May need special positioning for TOS

docs.title: CTV Abdomen Pelvis
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. Chen

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTV Venous Phase Contrast (180 sec delay) Diaphragm to Proximal femur
    • Deep vein thrombosis
    • May-Thurner syndrome
    • IVC filter placement planning
    • Venous malformation

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours
    • Pre-Medication:
      • Oral contrast optional

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 3 mL/s

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Scan at 180 seconds for venous phase. Slower injection rate OK for venous imaging. Scan from diaphragm to femoral veins
    • 18-20G IV

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history
    • Assess IVC iliac femoral veins for thrombosis. Look for compression (May-Thurner). Measure vessel caliber for filter sizing
    • Arms raised. May add leg veins if DVT suspected

docs.title: CTV Chest Abdomen Pelvis
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2024-01-15 Author: Dr. White

  • 1. Clinical Summary

    Acquisition SummaryClinical Indications Series Phase Coverage CTV Venous Phase Contrast (180 sec delay) Thoracic inlet to Proximal femur
    • Superior vena cava syndrome
    • Central venous occlusion
    • Tumor staging with venous involvement

  • 2. Patient Prep

    • Position: Supine with arms raised
    • NPO Status: NPO 2-4 hours

  • 3. IV Contrast & Injection

    Injection ParametersLab Requirements Parameter Value Agent Isovue 370 Volume 125 mL Flow Rate 3 mL/s

    Full dose if eGFR > 30

  • 4. Special Notes

    Technologist NotesNursing NotesRadiologist NotesTips & Tricks
    • Scan at 180 seconds. Include SVC through femoral veins. May need arm injection for SVC assessment
    • 18-20G IV - may need bilateral arm IVs for SVC

    Safety First

    • Renal Function: Verify eGFR > 30
    • Allergy: Check allergy history. May need bilateral IVs
    • Assess SVC IVC and major tributaries. Look for thrombosis compression or tumor invasion
    • Arms raised. For SVC consider bilateral arm injection

docs.title: Routine Head
docs.text: Last Updated: 2015-05-02 Protocol Author: Dr. Duncan Ferguson

docs.title: 1. Clinical Indications
docs.text:
• Bleed
  • Routine Head

docs.title: 2. Patient Prep & Screening
docs.text:
• Standard MRI safety screening.m
  • Patient to change into scrubs.
  • No IV contrast needed for routine exam.

docs.title: 3. Positioning & Coil
docs.text:
• Positioning: Supine, head first.
  • Coil: HRBRAIN, NV Array, HNS
  • Landmark: Center to head

docs.title: 6. Notes for Technologist
docs.text: -Axial - The slices should be parallel to a line of AC and PC or hard palate. Include from the base of the skull to the top of the head. Slices for T2 FSE and FLAIR and same coverage for DWI. * AX T2 FLAIR: Keep 30~32slices - Mar 2023 SPGR - COR Reformat Only(4x4mm,FOV=22cm) - Jan 4.2013 * Axial DWI(HiRes) – HDx(4NEX), HDe(2NEX)as per Dr. DH, GS – May01/2015

docs.title: MRI Brain without and with Contrast
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2023-10-27 Author: Dr. Emily White

  • 1. Clinical Indications

    • Multiple sclerosis evaluation
    • Seizure
    • Suspected tumor or mass

  • 2. Patient & Contrast Prep

    Safety First

    • Screening: Full MRI safety screen for implants/devices.
    • Renal: Check eGFR > 30 for contrast.
    • IV Access: 22g or larger.
    • Contrast Agent: Gadavist (0.1 mmol/kg)

docs.title: Protocol Details
docs.text: For Radiologist (Overview)For Technologist (Full Protocol)

docs.title: Sequence & Reconstruction Summary
docs.text: Phase / Type Sequence / Recon Key Features & Notes Pre-Contrast Sagittal T1 SE Midline Anatomy Axial T2 FLAIR Excellent for MS Lesions Axial DWI For Acute Stroke Post-Contrast Axial T1 SE FatSat 3D T1 MPRAGE 3D Isotropic Volume Reconstructions Coronal & Sagittal Reformats From 3D MPRAGE ADC Map From DWI

docs.title: Positioning & Coil
docs.text:
• Positioning: Supine, head-first.
  • Coil: Multi-channel Head Coil.
  • Landmark: Center at the nasion.

Straighten the Head

Use the laser alignment to ensure the head is perfectly straight. This is critical for good reformats.

docs.title: Sequence Parameters
docs.text: Plane Sequence Name Slice Thickness Notes Sagittal T1 SE 5 mm Localizer and midline anatomy. Axial T2 FSE 5 mm Standard T2 for pathology. Axial T2 FLAIR 5 mm Excellent for periventricular lesions (MS). Axial DWI 5 mm Run before contrast. Generates ADC map. Coronal T2 FSE 4 mm For temporal lobes and hippocampus. ---ADMINISTER IV CONTRAST--- Axial T1 SE FatSat 5 mm Post-contrast, check for fat saturation. Sagittal T1 MPRAGE 3D 1 mm (isotropic) High-res post-contrast volume.

docs.title: Post-Processing Instructions
docs.text:
• Reconstructions:
    • From the 3D T1 MPRAGE, create:
      • 3mm Axial reformats
      • 3mm Coronal reformats
      • 3mm Sagittal reformats
  • Sending: Send all acquired series and all three reformatted series to PACS.
